text:

Just a small request, though: would you mind putting your book recomendations and such in the video description or as a fixed comment in written form? replies.author: @dieselface1
replies.text: I've already made my point in a long wall of text in another comment, so I'll refrain from too long of a response here, but to sum up my response to Oberst Kawaii, A. Saying you want Jews or other people groups to die isn't attempting to kill Jews. And before you talk about threats of violence, yes, if someone were to say that they were going to kill Jews they should be arrested for that because that is a *direct threat of violence.* However using the excuse that because someone believes in the Nazi ideology as a pretext to take action, is declaring someone guilty of a crime they have not committed and technically haven't stated that they're going to commit, which goes against the major *left wing* judicial practice of innocent until proven guilty of the crime they are being prosecuted for, which in this case would be genocide. B. Even if you believe in locking someone up for speech, I hardly see how that excuses violence. Violence is an appropriate response to violence, but not to speech. If Richard Spencer and his goons were to go out and start attempting genocide, then you could go use all the violence you want to counteract that, hell, I'd join you.

One can visit a concentration camp and see that it was a place of real and unimaginable suffering and despair, a harsh reminder of what fascism lead to and what it can lead to again. replies.author: @dieselface1
replies.text:
I mostly don't see how people believe in the "tolerance paradox" when it comes to free speech, or in general. The "tolerance paradox" states that "if a society is tolerant without limit, its ability to be tolerant will eventually be seized or destroyed by the intolerant." If we are talking about speech specifically here, speech isn't intolerance, the speech of those that are intolerant is a symptom of intolerance. You don't cure a cold by suppressing the desire to sneeze, in fact it can make your cold worse because you're bottling up the virus inside of yourself, which is kind of analogous to real life as I'll touch on in a bit. Regardless, being tolerant of speech isn't being "infinitely tolerant" in any event anyway. No one on the left who talks in favor of free speech is in favor of tolerating, say, hate crimes. 
Speech in and of itself is not harmful in any tangible way. Though it can affect the way affect the way people think and, potentially, act, if you want to restrict free speech because free speech can lead to authoritarianism, then you are yourself advocating for a paradox: "In order to be anti-authoritarian we must be authoritarian." 
This being said, I did say "mostly don't understand" in the beginning because I do understand and agree with why someone would want so criminalize, say, a direct threat of violence, because A. it is pretty much always clear what is and what isn't a direct threat of violence, and B. a direct threat is a statement of intent for criminal wrongdoing, intent being integral to how and with what crime you charge someone  in the first place.
I believe however that ultimately restricting speech in cases other than threats of violence aren't helpful to society in any real way, and only fuel the right-wing victim narrative, and when they are being charged, they're technically right, as they are being persecuted over free speech in those instances.
Another funny thing about the "tolerance paradox" is that it is essentially right wing tribalistic thinking. A right winger could easily apply this "paradox" to entire populations, saying "if we're tolerant of people who are intolerant (i.e. Muslims, in their thinking), then we'll be destroyed by them."

replies.author: @janesimonson1163
replies.text:
If you're referring to Popper's 'The Open Society and it's Enemies', keep in mind the important caveats to that idea later in the book--he did not advocate for suppression of speech. In particular the popularly circulated comic does not include this, and I think it kind of misrepresents his point as a result.  I know as a concept it's used more broadly by a wide variety of people, though, and not all of them may share his initial thesis.

Although I think a few of the others in this thread go too far, there is a point in saying that suppression of dissenting ideas (even focusing on bigotry or disinformation) can as easily be turned on us and our beliefs by those who don't share them.  Unfortunately it's difficult to determine when speech is revealing the brink of violent or authoritarian action, and yet if it's not taken into account it can be too late.  At the least, I think it's important to cultivate minds critical about these tactics so they can see through them, rather than trying to silence those who espouse them...  But it often seems like people only grow less so as time goes on.

author: @rapunzel2028
text: Very good advice on history. I have a master's in it and any field, and subject has a "consensus" based on the historiography but it's never completely definitive since new scholarship is done all the time and thus new scholarship that might bring either new evidence or more likely another perspective changes our understanding of the subject. Contrary to what most think, history isn't so static and good luck to the questioner too.  Studying history can be difficult but rewarding :).

replies.author: @rapunzel2028
replies.text: @The Mad Menshevik oh many things and not just teaching. I work at an academic library. At times it's been used as a stepping stone to law school too.

replies.author: @rapunzel2028
replies.text: Yes. One can be surprised but the skills that are learned in history is essential in many different fields: making an argument, backing it up with evidence, considering different perspectives, etc..all that. It's very important and why many companies want people with those kind of skills: to discern information and use critical thinking.  Learning history can do that.

replies.author: @Ninchennase
replies.text:
I've got a degree in linguistics and have experienced the same. Many companies are quite eager these days to get other views than strictly business. Studying history, languages etc. means you're used to read a lot, to quickly digest huge amount of information, to develop new ideas out of that and to explain them to others. And also to question whether something's right or whether there are other, faster, better ways to do things. 
That's valuable for many companies. So I'm in online marketing spending a lot of time analyzing performance data, which has nothing to do with linguistics, but believe me: Staying up to date in this quickly changing business and explaining the changes to colleagues and customers is what I do really, really well. Oh, and I also write a lot of how-tos etc. Because seriously - learning how online marketing works isn't rocket science, it took me about 3 months for the basics and another 6 months to get the practice right. Since then it's just improvement. It doesn't require years of university, it's mostly statistics and a little bit of math and a lot of psychology.

replies.author: @Banjo-ed5vv
replies.text:
@doveyboy2 "true" stateless communism is a utopic wet dream of Karl "the anti-utopic science man" Marx. 
In retrospect his manifesto is riddled with unfullfilled predictions, such as his claim that due to the nature of a worker being a product in capitalism, his income/worth will be equal to the cost of the product (i.e bare minimum wage to sustain oneself). I know hindsight is 20/20 and all, but eh disputing "gib me free shit" santa is my favourite type of leisure. Cheers

author: @lildude67
text:
You should definitely do a video on what you call "fortified democracy".  In the USA it is very hard to object to any speech without being accused (generally falsely, but whole heartedly and honestly) of violating or wanting to violate the first amendment.

A recent example is Alex Jones.  I see no defense of his speech.  But many people from all points in the political spectrum defend him without much thought.

replies.author: @benevolentnick1
replies.text: I dont pay much attention to alot of things alex jones says these days but huge respect and kudos for him uncovering the appalling, tragic and simply terrifying goings on at the Seattle g20 conference.Which forces me to consider the many things he does say. Think you would find that very interesting (what jones uncovered)and worthwhile if only cause as a direct consequence of those actions every subsequent g20conference has been a masterclass of miss direction- masking some outrageous behavior and legal frameworks. Happy to inform you on some of those if you would like? Maybe you should start looking at the message not the messenger. And rather than being objectionable, start thinking/evaluating solutions to an identifiable issue. if you cant do the first part simply there is no issue that you should be concerning yourself with-unless its for further knowledge. And if your asking this question above you are so far away from having an ordered mind, i would caution you, stay away from religious people, nigerian heirs and dangerous idiots like 3 arrows.

replies.author: @dieselface1
replies.text: A couple of points to make in defense of Alex Jones from a leftist. To start off, I don't know all the specifics of why he's been banned, though i know it involved the Sandy Hook shooting and claiming that the parents were paid actors. Since he's defaming those people, I actually agree that the video should be pulled down. Should he be banned though? Imagine Alex Jones was sued for this (and I'm pretty sure he was) and the prosecution won, as they should, but the decision wasn't just that Jones should be punished for what he said, but should also be banned from speaking or in any way communicating in public. That's essentially what happened to him, just on social media. Furthermore, after Jones' banning from multiple social media sites, there's been a massive increase in the suspension, pulling down, and banning of political content and politically involved users and pages, both left and right. Turns out when you give silicon valley oligarchs an inch on whether they can restrict what you say online, they take a mile. This is also why I'm not in favor of the government criminalizing any speech other than defamation/slander (and only in cases where the victim is tangibly negatively affected), and  *direct* threats of violence. I don't exactly trust the government to tell people what is and isn't acceptable speech, *especially* the US government.

author: @voltairinekropotkin5581
text:
Kropotkin's _The Conquest of Bread_ isn't actually a good book to read as an intro to anarchism. It's written for people who already have a general understanding of socialism and anarchism. 

A much better intro is Peter Gelderloos's _Anarchy Works_ .

replies.author: @Dorian_sapiens
replies.text: Thanks. I'm about half-way through _Conquest_ and feeling like it's big-picture stuff, meanwhile I'm wondering how anarchy happens on a more granular level. I'll check out _Anarchy Works._

replies.author: @voltairinekropotkin5581
replies.text:
Dorian sapiens 

For getting into Kropotkin himself, a good intro is his longer pamphlets, which are usually collected in a single book. Those being 

‚Ä¢ _Anarchist Morality_
‚Ä¢ _Anarchism: Its Philosophy and Ideal_
‚Ä¢ _The State: Its Historic Role_ 
‚Ä¢ _The Modern State_
‚Ä¢ _War and Capitalism_ 

Most of which are found his the excellent anthology _Modern Science and Anarchy_ (edited with a long introduction by Iain McKay), which came out this year from AK Press

author: @janesimonson1163
text:
In regards to the question from the recent left-leaning individual in a conservative household:
I definitely agree with your response, not only does genuinely listening to the views they put forward help to create a dialogue of respect, it also allows you to better assess and address their points as time goes on.  If they're out and out not interested in discussion though, it'll be rough either way.

I'd also say to remember that the political dimension of a person is only one dimension of a person, even if it may impact others.  Even if it's not possible to agree on issues of principles or politics, there are other places still to find common ground if you so desire--which by the question, it sounds like they do.  For me at least, this has also been true outside of my family, as I've grown up in a relatively conservative community, and have had a good share of conservative friends, while I myself am left (and look the lefter still in my home country of the US...)  If we engaged purely on topics of politics there would have been little to keep us in touch, but we shared various other interests and activities, and over the course of some years of discourse better came to understand one another's positions, even if there was rarely much in the way of concessions more than the minor (with only one notable exception I can recall.)

As you said, it's hard to say anything without knowing more about their specific situation, but I guess the question made me reflect on my own experiences.

replies.author: @Sackofbooks
replies.text: That would explain all the skulls (apparently the protagonist of that game is trans?).

replies.author: @Sackofbooks
replies.text: Oh, I've never read any articles on the subject. I've just seen the theory proposed by random people on Twitter, and since there's nothing in canon to gainsay it I consider it a valid interpretation of the text.

replies.author: @Sackofbooks
replies.text:
That's your prerogative, but unless he puts a definitive statement on her gender identity into one of the games I don't consider his interpretation any more valid than anyone else's.

And again, I don't consider this a valid interpretation of the character because of the person who originated the theory. I consider it a valid interpretation because nothing in the game contradicts it.

replies.author: @Sackofbooks
replies.text:
I never said he was an invalid source of information. I said his word alone doesn't override this interpretation unless he puts a definitive statement on this matter in one of the Metroid games.

And I'm quite securely moored in reality. The game, however, is not. That's why it's possible for there to be multiple equally valid interpretations of it.

replies.author: @Sackofbooks
replies.text: As far as I know that is also a valid interpretation of the character.

replies.author: @Sackofbooks
replies.text:
I do not (although I have heard of her).

And for the record, a "valid" interpretation here is not the same as a "good" or "harmless" one. It just means that the interpretation is not contradicted by the text it is interpreting.

replies.author: @Sackofbooks
replies.text: I've been nothing but sincere throughout this conversation, but you're certainly entitled to think whatever you like about my statements.

author: @Dodovacer
text:
Sadly I could not find the person who commented and asked for your opinion on studying histoy. Therefore I like to give a "professional" (really big air quotes since I am just starting writing my PhD) opinion on it. The most valuable thing to have if you want to study history and even consider going into that direction professionally (PhD for teaching/research at university and/or working in adjected fields) is the ability to read a lot and read in many different languages. For example already for modern history if you are not a German or French nativ speaker many fields can be quiet difficult to handle (source-wise and literature-wise). If you already have a field of interest you want to study, like lets say communism, it might be necessary to even study something that is often refered to as an "area-study" in combination with history (like Sinology for Communist China or Slavistic for the Sowjet Union). 

The point I want to make is: Studying history to not only be a teacher but an actual researcher requires one to learn some kind of special language ability to stand out and then apply this ability to reading lots of stuff. Daniels suggestion ties into that too: It is firstly necessary to read several different publications (also in differently languages, since there are some big differences between the national discourses on most topics) to understand the academic discourse(s) and then judge the first hand accounts (which is stricly speaking only considered a source in history) with your own philological and theoretical tools. Therefore I would always suggest fellow students to pick up some special field of interest and maybe even couple it with a second degree in the appropriate language. (You can still learn languages late - its just more costly).

replies.author: @Dodovacer
replies.text: @The Mad Menshevik well it depends. But there has been a great presentation of the US context on askhistorians. I just wanted to add an opinion to what Daniel answered in the video.

author: @jkb_h7950
text:

author: @namenloss730
text:
I don't know enough about the Iron Front to say I would align  with them ideologically, all I know of is their opposition to fascism, communism, and monarchism. But I disagree that communism isn't prevalent enough for us to acknowledge it. We currently have 2 "soviet republics" in Ukraine, Venezuela collapsing under the current regime. I have classmates in grad school openly praising Lenin, Stalin, Mao, and even somehow Pol Pot (they lose any right to claim to be good people, especially with that last one). They spend their time making jokes about people pointing out the atrocities committed by the USSR, they out right deny the genocides, say the Gulags weren't that bad, etc... In a way extremely reminiscent of Holocaust deniers. Their antifa(TM) buddies openly call for violent revolution ("nothing can change without bloodshed", "The Bourgeois must all be killed", etc...). They really have a wish of power and control, they don't even pretend not to be authoritarians.

While I find the collectivist concept of communism to be something that could be good in a small community, naive for a small society, and outright dumb for large societies, I have nothing against it. I do have something against people who defend monsters and genocides, whatever side of the political spectrum they are on.

replies.author: @namenloss730
replies.text: I'm in France, from where I'm looking communism doesn't seem to be much more irrelevant than neo nazis. Our antifa(TM) branches are openly revolutionary communists, and at least brag about wanting to commit act of violence. I oppose authoritarianism and these guys are proudly anti democratic. Because of that I'm forced to be against antifa even though I oppose fascism.

replies.author: @soarel325
replies.text: The thing is that they're not a threat to wider society. I sometimes try and dunk on them online but they're not really a threat in the grand scheme of things, just some idiots on the internet.

replies.author: @namenloss730
replies.text: Except the ones I'm talking about will protest in the streets with banners calling for revolution and murder. They carry weapons around and think they have the moral right to attack people. Small threat yes, but still a threat.

author: @sunyavadin
text: On the first question - where the hell do people find all these youtube rightwingers? When I try to browse youtube for any particular political topic, I only ever see stuff like Contrapoints, Shaun, hbomberguy, Philosophy Tube, Zinnia Jones, Lindsay Ellis, Essenceofthought, Steve Shives, more AnCom/ML channels than I can count, non stop chapo trap house, and bigger networks like TYT. Like, I know Carl and a small circle of his hangers-on exist because he's the most common laughing stock on these channels, and the others tend to get mentioned in relation to him, I know Thunderf00t because before he vanished up his own arse, and lost all relevance a few years back he used to do some interesting science vids, and I know Dave Rubin literally only through him having used to be on TYT. And like, I guess the big corporate propaganda channels like Prager? But it always seems to be the same handful of names I see showing up, just the same small clique who want daddy Jordan to make them clean their room if they want lobster tonight or whatever.

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text: The thing is I have historically watched and even liked videos by some of these people, like when Rubin was still in TYT, or Thunderf00t was still doing science vids, so you'd expect youtube's recommendations to reflect that and at least throw me something now and again..

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text: But even when I'm on a private browsing window on someone else's computer and not logging in, like youtube never really throws these kinds of vids up. It seems they're pretty relegated to people in their own echo chambers who need to go looking for them, apart from the aforementioned ones like Prager which pay boatloads of money for promotions. I'll still see stuff like Contrapoints on the front page if she's done a new video, or at least one TYT story on the trump admin's latest firing or whatever, maybe a David pakman vid, but mostly it's a bunch of music or gaming, or trailers for the latest superhero movie - when I look for political topics there, the political stuff even on a virgin youtube view doesn't ever bring up your black pigeons or teal deers.

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text: I use tor, that does hide your IP, so....

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text: I mean it's possible library computers' general usage reflect a more left wing section of the population? But free public wifi?

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text: Well yeah, most people don't know what tor is, so I used a generic term people would recognise. But yeah on my home system I use tor any time I don't want to be tracked, on public systems I use private browsing, and I never log in to anything on a public connection. Basic internet hygeine.

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text: But if you're just here to troll, well fuck it, no point wasting my time even explaining stuff.

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text: Oh wow. Not even a troll, a *sockpuppet* of a troll. Impressive. Is it dummy accounts all the way down? I kinda wanna see how far the "my other account" trail goes XD

replies.author: @ernststravoblofeld
replies.text: sunyavadin This is a very important question. One of the most insidious things about the modern internet is the way algorithms only show you more of what you already know. Their only purpose is to hold your attention and so, keep your eyes on the screen. This is what drives the polarization of everything, which is ripping the world in half. This is why each side of any issue thinks the other side must be insane. You literally do not see what your opponent is consuming. He never sees where your ideas come from. Go study at a library. Physical books on shelves do not have an algorithm.

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text: But hey, neatly proving my point, the illusion of a more widespread presence beyond a couple of small youtube circle jerks is given by the abundance of sockpuppet accounts who "ironically" publicise them.

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text: Seriously though, trolls aside, I spend hours upon hours researching how youtube's systems work using alternate accounts and browsing whilst not logged in and from random ips, all because months ago I promised a bunch of people I'd try and figure out why they particularly are not getting all their subbed channels' videos showing up chronologically in their feed when it works fine for everyone else. I see nonpartisan blank unfiltered youtube every day in working towards this endeavour in trying to figure out what combination of settings or behaviours triggers it suddenly not working as intended. And on boxes where I've not looked at a single video, I see the bigger left-wing channels show up, but the so called "alt-right" stuff never finds its way to the front page, or when it does it's a TYT vid critical of Milo. I know how echo chambers work. And I'm pretty sure the narrative of this monolithic right wing presence on the platform is a product of such echo chambers, since it's not borne out by what one sees when they step outside their echo chamber.

replies.author: @sunyavadin
replies.text:
Like, it definitely seems like it's bigger than it is if every different channel you sub to has done an individual debunking of each of the same channel's videos. Which shows up when I *am* logged into my primary account.
Which is totally a good thing, and should be kept up.  
But stepping outside the echo chamber of your curated suggestions suddenly makes you realise how niche the stuff you see something about every day actually is.
